facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2272 of 1968 is an appeal from the judgment and order dated September 12, 1967 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 178 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2272 of 1968. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 12, 1967 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 178 of 1966.

facts.text: The respondent filed a writ petition challenging certain orders relating to assessment of sales tax.

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by certificate from a judgment of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in a writ petition filed by the respondent challenging certain orders relating to assessment of sales tax.

facts.text: The respondent held mineral concessions for extracting manganese ore in mining areas in Balaghat, Chhindwara, Bhandara and Nagpur districts in erstwhile State of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent held mineral concessions for extracting manganese ore in respect of mining areas in the districts of Balaghat, Chhindwara, Bhandara and Nagpur in the erstwhile State of Madhya Pradesh i.e. before the reorganisation of the State.

facts.text: Material period for assessment is from October 1, 1953 to December 26, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The material period, in the present case, is from October 1, 1953 to December 26, 1958.

facts.text: From October 1, 1953 to October 31, 1956, Nagpur and Bhandara districts formed part of Madhya Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: This may be split up into two periods 1 October 1, 1953 to October 31, 19S6 till that date Nagpur and Bhandara districts formed part of the State of Madhya Pradesh

facts.text: From November 1, 1956, Nagpur and Bhandara districts included in new State of Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: and 2 November 1, 1956 to December 26, 1958 from November 1, 1956 the aforesaid two districts came to be included in the new, State of Maharashtra .

facts.text: Respondent effected sales of manganese ore from mines during 1953-1958 without registering as dealer despite turnover exceeding limit.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant the respondent effected sales of manganese ore from the mines during the aforesaid periods without registering himself as a dealer in spite of the fact that the turnover exceeded the prescribed limit.

facts.text: Notices issued by Sales Tax Officer, Chhindwara to respondent to register and show cause under S.11(5) of Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: A number of notices were issued by the Sales Tax Officer, Chhindwara calling upon the respondent to get himself registered and to show cause why he should number be assessed under S. 1 1 5 of the Act of 1947

facts.text: Towards end of 1958, respondent applied for registration to Sales Tax Officer, Chhindwara Circle.

anchor.surface_text: Towards the end at the- year 1958 the- respondent applied for registration to the SalesTax Officer, Chhindwara Circle exercising jurisdiction over the Balaghat and Chhindwara districts.

facts.text: Registration certificate granted to respondent on December 27, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: On December 27, 1958 a registration certificate was granted to him.

facts.text: Sales Tax Officer issued notice under ss.17,18,19 of Act 1958 and assessed respondent for October 1, 1953 to December 26, 1958 for Rs. 31,580.42 tax and Rs. 5,000 penalty.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the Sales Tax Officer issued a numberice to the respondent under ss. 17, 18 19 of the Act of 1958. He proceeded to assess the respondent for the period October 1, 1953 to December 26, 1958. The amount assessed came to Rs. 31,580.42 and a penalty of Rs. 5,000 was imposed.

facts.text: Assessment order dated April 23, 1960 passed by Sales Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: challenging the order of assessment dated April 23, 1960 passed by the Sales tax Officer

facts.text: Respondent filed appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax, not admitted due to non-deposit of tax and penalty under s.38(3) Act 1958 or s.22 Act 1947.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent filed an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Sales Tax. As he did number deposit the past dues of the tax and the penalty demanded of him the appeal was number admitted in view of s. 38 3 of the Act of 1958 or s. 22 of the Act of 1947.

facts.text: Respondent preferred appeal to Board of Revenue on January 23, 1961 without depositing tax, appeal not admitted.

anchor.surface_text: On January 23, 1961 the respondent preferred an appeal to the Board of Revenue without depositing the amount of tax required to be deposited under the law. That appeal was also number admitted.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition under Art. 226 on March 28, 1966 challenging assessment order and appellate authorities' orders.

anchor.surface_text: On March 28, 1966 the respondent filed a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution challenging the order of assessment dated April 23, 1960 passed by the Sales tax Officer as also the orders of the appellate authorities.

facts.text: In writ petition, respondent claimed Sales Tax Officer had no jurisdiction to assess sales from Bhandara and Nagpur districts which were part of Maharashtra.

anchor.surface_text: 1 The Sales tax Officer Balaghat or Chhindwara had numberjurisdiction to assess the writ petitioner to tax in respect of sales which took place from the districts of Bhandara and Nagpur which were part of the State of Maharashtra.

facts.text: In writ petition, respondent claimed sales for export outside India not includible in taxable turnover.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales tax Officer had numberjurisdiction to include the sales in respect of manganese in the taxable turnover when those sales were for export outside India

facts.text: In writ petition, respondent claimed no power to assess under s.18(6) Act 1958 for period prior to April 1, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: The Sales tax Officer had numberpower to assess the writ petitioner under s. 18 6 of the Act of 1958 when the liability arose for the period prior to April 1, 1959

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court quashed the assessment order as a composite order due to lack of jurisdiction over Nagpur and Bhandara sales under s.78 States Reorganisation Act 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the Sales tax Officer, Balaghat, had numberjurisdiction to assess the tax with respect to sales effected from the mines in Nagpur and Bhandara districts. As the assessment order was a companyposite order it was liable to be quashed as a whole.

facts.text: Registration certificate granted in 1958 showed place of business at Katangjhiri in Balaghat district.

anchor.surface_text: So long as the assessee was number registered as a dealer with reference to any particular place of business it companyld number be said that Katangjhiri in Balaghat district was the place of business

issues.text: Whether the Sales Tax Officer Balaghat or Chhindwara had jurisdiction to assess the writ petitioner to tax in respect of sales which took place from the districts of Bhandara and Nagpur which were part of the State of Maharashtra

anchor.surface_text: 1  The Sales tax Officer Balaghat or Chhindwara had no jurisdiction to assess the writ petitioner to tax in respect of sales which took place from the districts of Bhandara and Nagpur which were part of the State of Maharashtra. As the order

issues.text: Whether the Sales Tax Officer had jurisdiction to include the sales in respect of manganese in the taxable turnover when those sales were for export outside India

anchor.surface_text: As the order of assessment included sales of ore from those districts also it was void. The Sales tax Officer had no jurisdiction to include the sales in respect of manganese in the taxable turnover when those sales were for export outside India

issues.text: Whether the Sales Tax Officer had power to assess the writ petitioner under s. 18(6) of the Act of 1958 when the liability arose for the period prior to April 1, 1959 when the provisions of the Act of 1947 were in force

anchor.surface_text: 4  That the assessments were barred by time.

issues.text: Whether tax liability under sales tax laws arises at the time of taxable event independent of assessment and quantification

anchor.surface_text: It is a part of the general scheme of all sales tax laws that taxes become due the moment a dealer makes either purchases or sales which are subject to taxation and the obligation to pay the tax arises. Although the tax liability which comes into existence cannot be enforced till the quantification is effected by assessment proceedings the liability for payment of tax is independent of the assessment

anchor.surface_text: It is a part of the general scheme of all sales tax laws that taxes become due the moment a dealer makes either purchases or sales which are subject to taxation and the obligation to pay the tax arises. Although the tax liability which companyes into existence cannot be enforced till the quantification is effected by assessment proceedings the liability for payment of tax is independent of the assessment

arguments.claim: Tax liability arises immediately upon taxable event, independent of assessment (citing Kedarnath Jute Mfg. Co. Ltd. v. CIT)

anchor.surface_text: See Kedarnath Jute Mfg. Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, Central Calcutta  1 . We have numberdoubt that the word arrears in respect of tax has been used in the sense of dues or what has become due by way of tax and that does number depend on assessment proceedings or quantification of the amount.

arguments.claim: Amounts due by way of tax not covered by residuary s.91; specifically dealt by s.78

anchor.surface_text: We do number companysider that the amounts due by way of tax are companyered by the residuary provisions i.e. S. 91 of the Act of 1956.

holdings.text: the word arrears in respect of tax has been used in the sense of dues or what has become due by way of tax and that does not depend on assessment proceedings or quantification of the amount

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's narrow interpretation as leading to uncertainty; relies on dictionary definitions, ordinary meaning, and sales tax scheme where dues exist prior to quantification; cites precedent

holdings.text: taxes become due the moment a dealer makes either purchases or sales which are subject to taxation and the obligation to pay the tax arises. Although the tax liability which comes into existence cannot be enforced till the quantification is effected by assessment proceedings the liability for payment of tax is independent of the assessment

anchor.surface_text: It is a part of the general scheme of all sales tax laws that taxes become due the moment a dealer makes either purchases or sales which are subject to taxation and the obligation to pay the tax arises. Although the tax liability which companyes into existence cannot be enforced till the quantification is effected by assessment proceedings the liability for payment of tax is independent of the assessment

holdings.reasoning_summary: General scheme of sales tax laws fixes liability at taxable event; enforcement delayed but existence independent; supported by precedent Kedarnath Jute

holdings.text: The right to recover arrears of any tax or duty ... shall belong to the successor State in whose territories the place of assessment of that tax or duty is included

anchor.surface_text: by referring to S. 78 of the States Reorganisation Act 1956. That section is in the following terms - The right to recover arrears of any tax or duty on property, including arrears of land revenue shall belong to the successor State in which the property is situated and the right to recover arrears of any other tax or duty shall belong to the successor State in whose territories the place of assessment of that tax or duty is included.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of s.78 SRA to facts; place of assessment by Sales Tax Officer Chhindwara/Balaghat situated in Madhya Pradesh territories post-reorganisation

holdings.text: ss. 78 and 83 indicate that when the question is of any tax or duty other than that on property the right has been conferred ... on the successor State in whose territories the place of assessment of that tax or duty is included

anchor.surface_text: Thus so far as taxes are concerned ss. 78 and 83 indicate that when the question is of any tax or duty other than that on property the right has been conferred and the liability imposed, in case of refund, on the successor State in whose territories the place of assessment of that tax or duty is included.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Part VII SRA; specific provisions for taxes prevail over general

holdings.text: We do not consider that the amounts due by way of tax are covered by the residuary provisions i.e. S. 91 of the Act of 1956

anchor.surface_text: We do number consider that the amounts due by way of tax are companyered by the residuary provisions i.e. S. 91 of the Act of 1956.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific provisions ss.78,83 govern tax arrears; residuary s.91 inapplicable to expressly covered matters

precedents.citation: Kedarnath Jute Mfg. Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, Central Calcutta  1

anchor.surface_text: Kedarnath Jute Mfg. Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, Central Calcutta  1

precedents.case_name: Kedarnath Jute Mfg. Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, Central Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: liability for payment of tax is independent of the assessment

justification_sets.label: Section 4, Central Provinces Berar Sales Tax Act 1947 support

anchor.surface_text: In our judgment arrears should be given their proper meaning as understood in the ordinary sense of that word. According to the Websters New International Dictionary arrears means among other things that which is behind in payment or which remains unpaid though due. The- example given is of arrears of rent, wages or taxes. In Strouds Judicial Dictionary, third edition, it has been stated that the word arrears presupposes a time fixed for payment of a sum of money and the lapse of time thereafter without payment. It is a part of the general scheme of all sales tax laws that taxes become due the moment a dealer makes either purchases or sales which are subject to taxation and the obligation to pay the tax arises. Although the tax liability which comes into existence cannot be enforced till the quantification is effected by assessment proceedings the liability for payment of tax is independent of the assessment  See Kedarnath Jute Mfg. Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, Central Calcutta  1 . We have no doubt that the word arrears in respect of tax has been used in the sense of dues or what has become due by way of tax and that does number depend on assessment proceedings or quantification of the amount. We do number consider that the amounts due by way of tax are companyered by the residuary provisions i.e. S. 91 of the Act of 1956.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court erred in interpretation of 'arrears' under s.78 of States Reorganisation Act; tax dues accrue at time of sale and right to recover belongs to successor State of place of assessment

anchor.surface_text: See Kedarnath Jute Mfg. Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, Central Calcutta  1 . We have no doubt that the word arrears in respect of tax has been used in the sense of dues or what has become due by way of tax and that does number depend on assessment proceedings or quantification of the amount.

In our judgment arrears should be given their proper meaning as understood in the ordinary sense of that word. According to the Websters New International Dictionary arrears means among other things that which is behind in payment or which remains unpaid though due. The- example given is of arrears of rent, wages or taxes. In Strouds Judicial Dictionary, third edition, it has been stated that the word arrears presupposes a time fixed for payment of a sum of money and the lapse of time thereafter without payment. It is a part of the general scheme of all sales tax laws that taxes become due the moment a dealer makes either purchases or sales which are subject to taxation and the obligation to pay the tax arises. Although the tax liability which comes into existence cannot be enforced till the quantification is effected by assessment proceedings the liability for payment of tax is independent of the assessment  See Kedarnath Jute Mfg. Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, Central Calcutta  1 . We have no doubt that the word arrears in respect of tax has been used in the sense of dues or what has become due by way of tax and that does number depend on assessment proceedings or quantification of the amount. We do number consider that the amounts due by way of tax are companyered by the residuary provisions i.e. S. 91 of the Act of 1956.

In our judgment arrears should be given their proper meaning as understood in the ordinary sense of that word. According to the Websters New International Dictionary arrears means among other things that which is behind in payment or which remains unpaid though due. The- example given is of arrears of rent, wages or taxes. In Strouds Judicial Dictionary, third edition, it has been stated that the word arrears presupposes a time fixed for payment of a sum of money and the lapse of time thereafter without payment. Although the tax liability which comes into existence cannot be enforced till the quantification is effected by assessment proceedings the liability for payment of tax is independent of the assessment  See Kedarnath Jute Mfg. Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income tax, Central Calcutta  1 . We have no doubt that the word arrears in respect of tax has been used in the sense of dues or what has become due by way of tax and that does number depend on assessment proceedings or quantification of the amount. We do number consider that the amounts due by way of tax are companyered by the residuary provisions i.e. S. 91 of the Act of 1956.

by referring to S. 78 of the States Reorganisation Act 1956. That section is in the following terms - The right to recover arrears of any tax or duty on property, including arrears of land revenue shall belong to the successor State in which the property is situated and the right to recover arrears of any other tax or duty shall belong to the successor State in whose territories the place of assessment of that tax or duty is included.

anchor.surface_text: Thus so far as taxes are concerned ss. 78 and 83 indicate that when the question is of any tax or duty other than that on property the right has been conferred and the liability imposed, in case of refund, on the successor State in whose territories the place of assessment of that tax or duty is included.

In our judgment arrears should be given their proper meaning as understood in the ordinary sense of that word. According to the Websters New International Dictionary arrears means among other things that which is behind in payment or which remains unpaid though due. The- example given is of arrears of rent, wages or taxes. In Strouds Judicial Dictionary, third edition, it has been stated that the word arrears presupposes a time fixed for payment of a sum of money and the lapse of time thereafter without payment. It is a part of the general scheme of all sales tax laws that taxes become due the moment a dealer makes either purchases or sales which are subject to taxation and the obligation to pay the tax arises. Although the tax liability which comes into existence cannot be enforced till the quantification is effected by assessment proceedings the liability for payment of tax is independent of the assessment  See Kedarnath Jute Mfg. We do number consider that the amounts due by way of tax are companyered by the residuary provisions i.e. S. 91 of the Act of 1956.
